name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1590-07-30

Diplomatic.text: I[ustus] Lipsius Car[olo] Clusio S[alutem] D[icit]. Quid tu ais? In Constantia mea damnavi flores? Imo illic quoque studium meum in eos aperui et affectum, quem tamen Langius noster nonnihil temperare volebat, ut omnia in humanis. At tu beabis me, si mittes. Scripsit ad te Raphelengius noster de conducenda illic tabena libraria. Rogo uti operam (quod in te est) ei naves. Nam divisio iam facta Plantinianorum et tota Typographia in duas partes secta, quarum altera hic, altera penes Mourentorfium est, ut puto te audisse. Dimissum Sylburgium a Wechelianis valde miror. Ille revera decus typographiae erat et labore atque industria itemque doctrina ad eas res valde aptus. Sed ipsi viderint. Epistolas meas cum grandiore item epistola sub Nundinas habebis. Haec nunc festine et breviter per occasionem, quia Raphelengius scribebat. Vale, mi Clusi. III Kal[endas] Sext[iles] MD.XC. [Address:] Cl[arissi]mo Viro Carolo Clusio. Francofurtum. [Clusii manu:] 1590. I[usti] Lipsii. Lugd[uno] Bata[vorum], III K[a]l[endas] Sex[tiles] novo calc[ulo] ad meas 21 Iunii vetere. Accepi Francuforti, 18 Aug[usti] vetere. Respondi 21 Sept[embris].

divisio ... facta: In his testament, Plantin, who died on 1 July 1589, bequeathed the Leiden branch of the Officina to his son-in-law Raphelengius; the Antwerp branch with everything it envolved and the whole supply of books and paper was left to his second son-in-law, Johannes Moretus.

annotations.text: Langius: Carolus Langius (De Langhe; 1521 – Liège, 1573), canon in Liège, humanist who published annotated editions of some of Cicero’s works (1563). He owned an impressive collection of manuscripts and early printed books. Main character of Lipsius’s De constantia, which was shaped as a dialogue between the mature Langhius and a still young Lipsius in Liège, partly even in Langius’s beautiful garden.
